title: Building from Source
para:
Installing from source will involve the following steps: getting the source, resolving dependencies, configuration, compilation, testing, and installation. The &app; installation process is fairly standard:
./autogen.sh ./configure <options> make make check make install
Continue reading for detailed step-by-step instructions of the entire procedure.

sect3.title: Getting the Source
sect3.para: &app; is available as a release tarball, a development checkout, or a development snapshot.

sect4.title: Releases
sect4.para: The source can be acquired from a GNU FTP Mirror. The release version is intended to be stable, and is probably your best choice if the release took place recently. If you need features or fixes which were introduced after the release, consider a CVS checkout or the daily snapshot.
To download, select a mirror near you, then choose the gnash directory.

sect4.title: Repository
sect4.para: The latest development sources are available via anonymous CVS (leave the password blank). This is recommended if you need features or bug fixes which were introduced after the last release. Look at the daily snapshot if you experience difficulty accessing the repository.

First set the environment variable CVS_RSH to 'ssh', as shown in this example, which uses the GNU Bourne-Again shell (bash):
export CVS_RSH="ssh" cvs -z3 -d:pserver:anonymous@cvs.sv.gnu.org:/sources/gnash co gnash
It is also possible to browse the repository on the web.

sect4.title: Snapshot
sect4.para: The daily development snapshot can be downloaded from http://www.gnashdev.org/dev_snapshots/. This is the best option if you need changes which were introduced after the last release of &app;, but are unable to download directly from the repository.
